Audi racing ahead in the prestige brand market

The new car merry-go round is spinning fast at Audi. And the firm is pushing the pace as it cements its place among the world's prestige brands.

The last couple of years have seen new models come hard and fast. We've seen the super impressive Audi A8, high performance S4, the dual-purpose Allroad, the latest Audi A6 and a second generation baby A3, the first generation of which sold 875,000 worldwide.

The Audi A3 is the starter car in the Audi family line-up and runs hard up against some of the toughest rivals in the business - starting with the BMW 1-Series, but including everything from the Alfa Romeo 147 to Volvo's smart and impressive new S40.

The look is new, but the real innovation is in the mechanical package. The pricing is pretty sharp, too - starting at pounds 15,510 for the 1.6-litre entry level model.

There is no escaping the mechanical links between the Audi A3 and the fifth generation Golf because both come from the Volkswagen Group family, but the prestige leader can claim the high ground as it hit the road first.

Audi manages to do it with everything from a new suspension system to electromechanical power steering as well as a major first - a direct fuel injection system as fitted to my test car. That's on top of active head restraints and an electronic stabilitysystem for safety.

The FSI engine comes with 150PS of power and 147lb/ft of torque but Audi is rightly making big claims about the car's response, economy and efficiency rather than its out-andout performance.

For the record it will sprint to 62mph in just over nine seconds and top 130mph in the right conditions. Out on the open road it will average over 40mpg which is better than good for any sporty two-litre hatchback.

It didn't take me long to warm to the Audi A3. It could have been the look or just the overall refinement. Audi obviously takes a lot of trouble over build quality although I think the car's superb fit and finish hides some of its personality.

The Audi A3 is a top car and very enjoyable but you have to dig quite deep to expose its inner strengths. They come from the responsive and refined engine and a suspension that copes easily with bumps and curves.

The Audi A3 makes a strong first impression, thanks to a cabin that must be the benchmark in its class and which reflects Audi's commitment to producing the best-quality cockpits in the business. It is everything from the red leather seats in the test car andred lit night lights to the panel shut gaps, quality finishes and the combination of materials used.

Powered by the two-litre petrol engine, which uses a common rail system identical to that in diesel cars for extra fuel efficiency, the FSI gets along very nicely with a combination of light and easy cruising and foot-down fun.

Audi has made the Audi A3 feel more agile than before with a more sophisticated suspension so that it doesn't lean quite so much through bends as one of Sir Richard Branson's Pendolino high-speed trains.

The result is it tracks round bends as if it was on a TGV line, by which I mean it doesn't alter its angle mid-corner if you play about with the accelerator when going briskly.

The engine is sweet and responsive which means you can glide along motorways.

The six-speed manual gearbox, with its crisp and instant changes, is among the best I've ever used. In fact, the whole Audi A3 experience is smart and impressive - and good value.

Alistair Coull
Birmingham Post
August 20, 2004
